Award.AwardTitle: Automorphic forms, Galois representations and ramification
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project ``Automorphic forms, Galois representations and ramification'' deals with some of the key issues that occupy modern algebraic number theory. They relate to the study of algebraic extensions of the rationals, and some of their more elusive properties that are not accessible by direct means. One uses automorphic forms to construct algebraic extensions of the rationals, which gives greater control on some of the basic properties that one would like to know about such extensions. The PI proposes to continue this theme of his work by using congruences between modular forms to produce extensions of number fields with controlled ramification. Such a control is related to classical conjectures like the Leopoldt conjecture. He will also continue the study of attaching automorphic forms to Galois representations, and proving more cases of the inverse Galois problem.


Work on the connection between automorphic forms and number theory is a very active area of number theory. This has broad implications which might also be useful to applications of number theory in areas like cryptography that are of practical use.
The PI also expects to continue to disemminate knowledge by involving students in research projects, by organising conferences, and giving talks aimed at broad audiences about his subject.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The  project on Automorphic forms, Galois representations and ramification focussed on investigating the hidden and important relatonships between automorphic forms (objects that are analytic in nature), Galois representations (objects that are algebraic in nature), and motives (objects which are motivic in nature). The tool used by the PI and his collborators was to study these relationships by using methods of ramification which have an algebraic, analytic and geometric aspect. The relationship invetigated is at the heart of number thoery and has played a decisive role in major developments in the subject including the proof of Fermat's Last Theorem and the modularity conjecture of J.-P. Serre. The PI also invetigated how some of these relationships between automorphic forms, Galois representations and motives, especially mediated through properties of ramification, has a bearing on other important problems in the subject like Leopoldt's conjecture. 

The techniques developed during the project add to the repertoire of methods to understand classical problems in algebaric number theory using the modern tools of arithmetic geometry, Galois cohomology and modular forms. 

 

The use of auxiliary ramification has played an important role in algebric number theory since the work of Cebotarev and Emil Artin on class filed theory in the early part of the 20th century. Such techniques promise to be of great relevance in the future as well especially when combined with the techniques of arithmetic geometry and automorphic forms. 

 

Modern algebraic number theory, arithmetic geometry and automorphic forms topics that are central to the PI's work has resulted in solution of long standing problems in the subject like Serre's conjecture.  Building on this work and extending its validity to higher dimensional situations is likely to be central to number theory. Algebraic number theory has had surprising impact on applications of number theory to cryptography, error-correcting codes.
